doc.field: CFD analysis for offshore systems: validation and applications Análise de CFD para sistemas offshore: validação e aplicações Análisis de CFD para sistemas offshore: validación y aplicaciones Daniel Fonseca de Carvalho e Silva Paulo Roberto Pagot Abstract The Ocean Engineering group in the Petrobras Research Center develops and applies multidisciplinary simulation tools for several engineering problems mainly related to offshore systems. Recently, there have been many different cases where Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) has been successfully employed. This study presents a collection of cases where CFD simulations were validated against experimental data and directly used to facilitate solutions for practical problems. Case #01 calculated the maritime current loads on an FPSO and investigated the influence of appendices such as bilge keels and rudders on the near flow field. Similarly, Case #02 extends this procedure to the identification of wind loads. Case #03 calculates the hydrodynamic forces on a torpedo anchor during its installation. The simulation results coupled with a simplified dynamic model facilitates the directional stability of different torpedo models to be evaluated. A whole FPSO topside geometry is modeled in Case #04, which investigates the flow pattern near the FPSO Helideck. The simulation velocity and turbulence profiles were compared to wind tunnel measurements. These summarized cases show how CFD tools can be advantageously applied to solve many practical problems. All these simulations were performed using Ansys CFX®. keywords: ■ CFD ■ offshore ■ aerodynamics ■ hydrodynamics ■ helideck ■ torpedo anchor Resumo O Grupo de Engenharia Oceânica no Centro de Pesquisas da Petrobras desenvolve e aplica ferramentas multidisciplinares de simulação para vários problemas de engenharia, principalmente àqueles relacionados a sistemas offshore. Recentemente, tem havido muitos casos diferentes onde a Mecânica dos Fluidos Computacional (CFD) tem sido empregada com sucesso. Este estudo apresenta uma coletânea de casos em que simulações foram validadas com dados experimentais e foram utilizadas diretamente para facilitar soluções de problemas práticos. No caso #01 as cargas associadas à correnteza foram calculadas sobre um FPSO e foi investigada a influência de apêndices, tais como bolinas e lemes, no fluxo ao redor da embarcação. Da mesma forma, o caso #02 estende este procedimento para a identificação das cargas de vento. O caso #03 calcula as forças hidrodinâmicas sobre um torpedo de ancoragem durante a sua instalação. Os resultados da simulação, acoplados a um modelo dinâmico simplificado, facilitam a investigação da estabilidade direcional de diferentes modelos de torpedos. A geometria de todo convés de um FPSO foi modelado no caso #04, que investiga o padrão de fluxo ao redor do heliponto da unidade. Os perfis de velocidade e turbulência simulados foram comparados com medições em túnel do vento. A apresentação resumida desses casos mostra como as ferramentas de CFD podem ser vantajosamente aplicadas para resolver muitos problemas práticos. Todas as simulações foram realizadas com o Ansys CFX®. palavras-chave: ■ CFD ■ offshore ■ aerodinâmica, ■ hidrodinâmica, ■ heliponto ■ torpedo de ancoragem Resumen El Grupo de los Ingeniería Oceánica en el Centro de Investigación de Petrobras, desarrolla y aplica las herramientas multidis-ciplinarias de simulación para diversos problemas de ingeniería, especialmente los relacionados con los sistemas de offshore. Recientemente, ha habido muchos casos diferentes donde la Mecánica de Fluidos Computacional (CFD) se han empleado con éxito. Este estudio presenta una colección de casos en que las simulaciones fueron validadas con datos experimentales y fue-ron utilizadas directamente para facilitar soluciones de problemas prácticos. En el caso de #01 los cargos relacionados con la corriente, se han calculado en un FPSO e fueron investigados con la influencia de apéndices, tales como sobrequillas y timones en el flujo alrededor del buque. Del mismo modo, caso #02 se extiende este procedimiento para la identificación de las cargas de viento. El caso #03, calculó las fuerzas hidrodinámicas en un torpedo de anclaje durante la instalación. Los resultados de la simulación, junto con un modelo dinámico simplificado, facilitaron la investigación de la estabilidad direccional de los modelos diferentes en los torpedos siendo evaluados. La geometría de la cubierta entera de un FPSO se ha modelado en el caso #04, que investigó el patrón de flujo alrededor de la pista de aterrizaje de la unidad. Los perfiles de velocidad y la turbulencia simulada se compararon con las mediciones en el túnel de viento. Una breve presentación de estos casos muestra cómo las herramientas de CFD pueden ser útiles para resolver muchos problemas prácticos. Todas estas simulaciones se llevaron a cabo con Ansys CFX®. palabras-clave: ■ CFD ■ offshore ■ aerodinámica ■ hidrodinámica ■ helipuerto ■ torpedos de anclaje Introduction Traditionally the presented cases would have been evaluated through experimental techniques. Nowadays, the use of simulation tools associated with those experiments provides a complete understanding of the best engineering solution for each case. For routine tests, the use of a carefully validated computational model may even substitute the experiments, reducing cost and time during the project development phase. All the studied cases were validated against experiments, and figure 1 presents the reduced models as examples for each case discussion. As illustrated, a towing tank was used to determine the current loads and an ocean basin was employed for the torpedo directional stability evaluation. For the wind loads and helideck turbulence calculation, a wind tunnel was necessary. All this equipment has a significant cost and a limited timeframe for tests. Therefore, attention was focused to efficiently validate these applications and the results are presented as follows: Case #01 - To determine current loads on offshore units To predict a floating unit dynamic behavior as well as calculate its mooring lines loads, the loads caused by the sea water flow around the unit hull must be identified. Case #02 - To determine wind loads on offshore units The wind loads also need to be evaluated for offshore units for the same reasons described in the previous case. Therefore, a very similar procedure was developed to calculate the forces and moments induced by the airflow around an offshore unit (Silva and Silva, 2010). Using a domain based on the mean surface level (equivalent to the wind tunnel floor) and considering only the platform geometry above the water line, again a steady state simulation was conducted for each individual he ading angle condition. The geometry and mesh of a drilling unit as well as a comparison between simulation wind tunnel measurements (Clausen, 2008) are shown in figure 4. Case #03 - Torpedo anchor directional stability during installation The geometry of offshore anchors is usually determined from a geotechnical perspective. This case proposes simple modifications to a torpedo anchor to improve its hydrodynamic performance related to its directional stability. Additionally, a real case of a damaged torpedo was investigated. Although the directional stability investigation requires a dynamic analysis, the CFD simulations were performed in a steady state regime to show from which inclinations the anchor tends to recover the vertical position. Pressure contours and streamlines for the torpedo for several inclination angles can be seen in figure 5. Using the simulation results, a diagram can be built to compare the directional stability of different torpedo models, based on the restoration moment coefficient (Cmy) and the inclination angle. This diagram, presented for four different torpedo models in figure 6, shows which alternative is more stable. The TORP2 in the figure was chosen based on this analysis and experimental tests. This model was recently successfully launched. Case #04 - Airflow Investigation around an offshore helideck Any aircraft flight maneuvering near offshore installations is strongly dependent on the local air flow conditions. The large number of platform topside modules represents obstacles from the flow perspective. Perturbations promoted by these obstacles influence the flow pattern near the offshore unit, including the helideck airspace. It is almost impossible to have a flow over the helideck totally free from the effect of nearby structures. Therefore, a validated simulation tool is necessary to investigate the obstacles influence on the flow field near helidecks (Silva et al., 2010). This case study was performed on a typical Petrobras FPSO unit installation. In addition, there are great obstacles to the wind flow aligned with the ship longitudinal axis. Both experiments and simulation showed that the highest turbulence regions are on the sides of the helideck, and not directly over the landing area. This analysis is in agreement with the conditions described by the helicopter pilots. The PIV low sampling frequency is the probable cause of the large differences between PIV and CTA measurements of SW. Conclusions This study summarizes the application of CFD to offshore systems, showing that this technique is already suitable for many practical problems investigated by the Petrobras Research Center. These case studies lead to the following conclusions: (i) current and wind loads can be calculated with the required precision for naval applications; (ii) using a simplified model, torpedo directional stability can be quickly estimated; (iii) the turbulence surrounding helidecks can be qualitatively predicted. In addition to the specific conclusions for each case, these studies showed that the use of CFD tools, have to be coupled with experiments and the knowledge of the simulation models limitations so that useful data for engineering applications can be produced. ■ ■ ■ Referências Bibliográficas ■ CIVIL AVIATION AUTHORITY.
